Course Description: The Course seeks to provide a historical glimpse to the poetry which has existed in the Indic tradition. It will dwell on classical Sanskrit poetry, Hindi-Urdu poetry, and Indian English poetry and major figures/poets who represent each of these phases.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to discuss the Sanskrit origins of poetry in India.
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to discuss evolution of Hindi and Urdu along with the poetry (and literature in the two languages)
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to analyse Indian English poetry, its characteristics and major poets from this phase.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students are able to discuss evolution of Hindi and Urdu along with the poetry (and literature in the two languages)

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introductory lecture - origin of poetry; what is poetry; beginnigs of poetry in the Indian subcontinent.
Natyashastra (Indian poetics and dramaturgy) and Smriti-Shruti sahitya
The Panch-Mahakavya - the five great poems of Sanskrit tradition
Introduction – Origin and evolution of Hindi and Urdu along with their literatures. The Hindi-Urdu-Hindustani debate.
Amir Khusrau - The poet, his couplets and riddles
Ghalib - the man and his shayari
Ramdhari Singh Dinkar (Excerpt from Rashmirathi) / Harivansh Rai Bachchan (Excerpt from Madhushala)
Introduction to Indian English Poetry/Literature and its three phases
Kamala Das - The Relationship, An Introduction
Vikram Seth - Sampati, Last Night, Distressful Homonyms
